thread.title: Mundine vs Green rivalry follows familiar script
thread.title_full: Mundine vs Green rivalry follows familiar script

title: Mundine vs Green rivalry follows familiar script
text:
Anthony Mundine vs Danny Green boxing rivalry follows familiar script By Corbin Middlemas Posted February 02, 2017 10:23:39 Map: Adelaide 5000 
Boxing has always marketed its ethnic, racial and national rivalries for better and for worse. 
The Anthony Mundine and Danny Green rivalry, which has gained unprecedented mainstream media attention for well over a decade, has similar themes. 
Whether it is an Irish fighter against an eastern European Jewish fighter last century, or a Puerto Rican boxer against a Mexican boxer, audiences have always been there in this way. 
Prior to World War II, Joe Louis (United States) and Max Schmeling (Germany) fought in a bout to symbolise the struggle of the time between democracy and fascism. 
It is the laziest and easiest way to promote, and does not require a huge amount of imagination. 
Boxing is unlike other sports. You tend to pick a side and it becomes an emotional thing for you. 
Since crossing over from rugby league in 2000, Mundine has worn the black hat in boxing's theatre. 
He virtually hand-picked Green as his chief rival, an opponent who appeals to mainstream Australia. 
Earlier this week, Mundine reiterated his intention to follow the lead of NFL quarterback Colin Kaepernick and refuse to stand for the national anthem ahead of his bout with Green at Adelaide Oval on Friday night. 
Mundine's actions have been labelled 'un-Australian' by some commentators. 
In fact it is, very Australian. It is not obligatory to stand for the anthem, as is our democratic right. 
It is anti-Australian at its core to encourage people to conform to what they believe is unjust. 
Mundine's eloquence is sometimes lacking, but his conscience would not allow him to stand until the inequality he sees is remedied. 
Education and income still differ along racial lines in this country. 
The anomaly of the entire sideshow is that it is commonplace in boxing for the anthems to be sung before either fighter leaves the dressing room. 
Mundine steps between the ropes a substantial underdog on Friday night. 
The most salient question going in is whether Mundine can take Green's power? 
Mundine does not take the best punch even against fighters his own size. 
Historically, there are so few examples of larger power punches being upset by light punching smaller fighters. 
For this reason, it is the kind of fight that can end at any moment.
